trans-unit.source: Service REST API Reference
trans-unit.target: Service REST API Reference

trans-unit.source: Azure Search Service REST API
trans-unit.target: Azure Search Service REST API

trans-unit.source: Azure Search is a cloud-based service that you can use to build custom search applications.
trans-unit.target: Azure Search is a cloud-based service that you can use to build custom search applications.

trans-unit.source: Azure Search has the concepts of <newTerm>search services</newTerm> and <newTerm>indexes</newTerm>, where a search service contains one or more indexes.
trans-unit.target: Azure Search has the concepts of <newTerm>search services</newTerm> and <newTerm>indexes</newTerm>, where a search service contains one or more indexes.

trans-unit.source: Your search service is uniquely identified by a fully-qualified domain name (for example: `mysearchservice.search.windows.net`).
trans-unit.target: Your search service is uniquely identified by a fully-qualified domain name (for example: `mysearchservice.search.windows.net`).

trans-unit.source: An api-key is generated when the service is provisioned, and is used to authenticate requests to your Azure Search service.
trans-unit.target: An api-key is generated when the service is provisioned, and is used to authenticate requests to your Azure Search service.

trans-unit.source: There are three types of operations that can be executed against the Azure Search Service:
trans-unit.target: There are three types of operations that can be executed against the Azure Search Service:

trans-unit.source: <legacyLink xlink:href="028bc3ff-387f-4a42-a485-a32262508be9" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Index operations</legacyLink>: Create, delete, update, or populate a search index.
trans-unit.target: <legacyLink xlink:href="028bc3ff-387f-4a42-a485-a32262508be9" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Index operations</legacyLink>: Create, delete, update, or populate a search index.

trans-unit.source: <legacyLink xlink:href="86722ded-daf6-4776-b984-b0dfd48218c0" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Document operations</legacyLink>: Query the index and lookup specific documents.
trans-unit.target: <legacyLink xlink:href="86722ded-daf6-4776-b984-b0dfd48218c0" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Document operations</legacyLink>: Query the index and lookup specific documents.

trans-unit.source: <legacyLink xlink:href="99bd2afa-3413-424c-a54a-58c8bb12bdbe" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Indexer operations</legacyLink>: Automate aspects of an indexing operation by configuring a <languageKeyword>data source</languageKeyword> and an <languageKeyword>indexer</languageKeyword> that you can schedule or run on demand.
trans-unit.target: <legacyLink xlink:href="99bd2afa-3413-424c-a54a-58c8bb12bdbe" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Indexer operations</legacyLink>: Automate aspects of an indexing operation by configuring a <languageKeyword>data source</languageKeyword> and an <languageKeyword>indexer</languageKeyword> that you can schedule or run on demand.

trans-unit.source: This feature is supported for a limited number of data source types.
trans-unit.target: This feature is supported for a limited number of data source types.

trans-unit.source: A separate API is provided for service administration.
trans-unit.target: A separate API is provided for service administration.

trans-unit.source: Examples of service administration operations include provisioning the service or altering capacity.
trans-unit.target: Examples of service administration operations include provisioning the service or altering capacity.

trans-unit.source: For more information about this API, see <link xlink:href="25dbc5b6-5251-42b6-9dc4-c7e3e3e7aa80" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Azure Search Management REST API</link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about this API, see <link xlink:href="25dbc5b6-5251-42b6-9dc4-c7e3e3e7aa80" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Azure Search Management REST API</link>.

trans-unit.source: The APIs documented in this section provide access to operations on search data, such as index creation and population, document upload, and queries.
trans-unit.target: The APIs documented in this section provide access to operations on search data, such as index creation and population, document upload, and queries.

trans-unit.source: When calling the API, keep the following points in mind:
trans-unit.target: When calling the API, keep the following points in mind:

trans-unit.source: All APIs must be issued over HTTPS (on the default port 443).
trans-unit.target: All APIs must be issued over HTTPS (on the default port 443).

trans-unit.source: All APIs must be accompanied with an <languageKeyword>api-key</languageKeyword> in the header or in the query string.
trans-unit.target: All APIs must be accompanied with an <languageKeyword>api-key</languageKeyword> in the header or in the query string.

trans-unit.source: All API requests must include the <languageKeyword>api-version</languageKeyword> in the URI.
trans-unit.target: All API requests must include the <languageKeyword>api-version</languageKeyword> in the URI.

trans-unit.source: Its value must be set to the version of the current service release, shown in the following example:
trans-unit.target: Its value must be set to the version of the current service release, shown in the following example:

trans-unit.source: All API requests can optionally set the Accept HTTP header.
trans-unit.target: All API requests can optionally set the Accept HTTP header.

trans-unit.source: If is not set, the default is assumed to be <codeInline>application/json</codeInline>.
trans-unit.target: If is not set, the default is assumed to be <codeInline>application/json</codeInline>.

trans-unit.source: Endpoint
trans-unit.target: Endpoint

trans-unit.source: The endpoint for service operations is the URL of the Azure Search service you provisioned: https://<yourService>.search.windows.net.
trans-unit.target: The endpoint for service operations is the URL of the Azure Search service you provisioned: https://<yourService>.search.windows.net.

trans-unit.source: Versions
trans-unit.target: Versions

trans-unit.source: <codeInline>api-version=2015-02-28</codeInline> is the general release version.
trans-unit.target: <codeInline>api-version=2015-02-28</codeInline> is the general release version.

trans-unit.source: This version operates under an Azure service level agreement (SLA).
trans-unit.target: This version operates under an Azure service level agreement (SLA).

trans-unit.source: Previous versions of the API were introduced during the public preview, starting with <externalLink><linkText>Azure Search Service REST API: 2014-07-31-Preview</linkText><linkUri>http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/articles/search-api-2014-07-31-preview/</linkUri></externalLink>.
trans-unit.target: Previous versions of the API were introduced during the public preview, starting with <externalLink><linkText>Azure Search Service REST API: 2014-07-31-Preview</linkText><linkUri>http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/articles/search-api-2014-07-31-preview/</linkUri></externalLink>.

trans-unit.source: <link xlink:href="62ffee0b-ae3b-46c1-9ddb-a372d21c6f4d" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Search service versioning</link> provides more information.
trans-unit.target: <link xlink:href="62ffee0b-ae3b-46c1-9ddb-a372d21c6f4d" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Search service versioning</link> provides more information.

trans-unit.source: Authentication and Access Control
trans-unit.target: Authentication and Access Control

trans-unit.source: Authentication to an Azure Search service requires two pieces of information: a search service URL and an <languageKeyword>api-key</languageKeyword>.
trans-unit.target: Authentication to an Azure Search service requires two pieces of information: a search service URL and an <languageKeyword>api-key</languageKeyword>.

trans-unit.source: The <languageKeyword>api-keys</languageKeyword> are generated when the service is created, and can be regenerated on demand after the service is provisioned.
trans-unit.target: The <languageKeyword>api-keys</languageKeyword> are generated when the service is created, and can be regenerated on demand after the service is provisioned.

trans-unit.source: An <languageKeyword>api-key</languageKeyword> is one of the following types:
trans-unit.target: An <languageKeyword>api-key</languageKeyword> is one of the following types:

trans-unit.source: Key
trans-unit.target: Key

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: Limits
trans-unit.target: Limits

trans-unit.source: Admin
trans-unit.target: Admin

trans-unit.source: Grants access to all operations, including the ability to create and delete <languageKeyword>indexes</languageKeyword>, <languageKeyword>indexers</languageKeyword>, and <languageKeyword>data sources</languageKeyword>.
trans-unit.target: Grants access to all operations, including the ability to create and delete <languageKeyword>indexes</languageKeyword>, <languageKeyword>indexers</languageKeyword>, and <languageKeyword>data sources</languageKeyword>.

trans-unit.source: Maximum of 2 per service
trans-unit.target: Maximum of 2 per service

trans-unit.source: Query
trans-unit.target: Query

trans-unit.source: Read-only access to indexes and documents, typically distributed to client applications that issue search requests.
trans-unit.target: Read-only access to indexes and documents, typically distributed to client applications that issue search requests.

trans-unit.source: 50 per service
trans-unit.target: 50 per service

trans-unit.source: Access control is limited to service administration via the role-based access controls (RBAC) provided in the Azure Preview Portal.
trans-unit.target: Access control is limited to service administration via the role-based access controls (RBAC) provided in the Azure Preview Portal.

trans-unit.source: Roles are used to set levels of access for service administration.
trans-unit.target: Roles are used to set levels of access for service administration.

trans-unit.source: For example, viewing the admin key is restricted to the Owner and Contributor roles, whereas viewing service status is visible to members of any role.
trans-unit.target: For example, viewing the admin key is restricted to the Owner and Contributor roles, whereas viewing service status is visible to members of any role.

trans-unit.source: Data operations performed against a Search service endpoint, including index management, index population, and queries, are accessed via <codeInline>api-keys</codeInline> exclusively.
trans-unit.target: Data operations performed against a Search service endpoint, including index management, index population, and queries, are accessed via <codeInline>api-keys</codeInline> exclusively.

trans-unit.source: RBAC does not apply to either index or document-related operations.
trans-unit.target: RBAC does not apply to either index or document-related operations.

trans-unit.source: To learn more about <codeInline>api-keys</codeInline> or RBAC as it relates to Azure Search, see <externalLink><linkText>Manage your Search service</linkText><linkUri>http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/articles/search-manage/</linkUri></externalLink>.
trans-unit.target: To learn more about <codeInline>api-keys</codeInline> or RBAC as it relates to Azure Search, see <externalLink><linkText>Manage your Search service</linkText><linkUri>http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/articles/search-manage/</linkUri></externalLink>.

trans-unit.source: It is considered a poor security practice to pass sensitive data such as an <codeInline>api-key</codeInline> in the request URI.
trans-unit.target: It is considered a poor security practice to pass sensitive data such as an <codeInline>api-key</codeInline> in the request URI.

trans-unit.source: For this reason, Azure Search will only accept a query key as an <codeInline>api-key</codeInline> in the query string, and you should avoid doing so unless the contents of your index should be publicly available.
trans-unit.target: For this reason, Azure Search will only accept a query key as an <codeInline>api-key</codeInline> in the query string, and you should avoid doing so unless the contents of your index should be publicly available.

trans-unit.source: As a general rule, we recommend passing your <codeInline>api-key</codeInline> as a request header.
trans-unit.target: As a general rule, we recommend passing your <codeInline>api-key</codeInline> as a request header.

trans-unit.source: Summary of APIs for creating and using an index
trans-unit.target: Summary of APIs for creating and using an index

trans-unit.source: The Azure Search Service API supports two syntaxes for entity lookup: simple and alternative OData syntax (see <link xlink:href="9274de9b-5faa-449b-9c5f-1ff54aa3afd9" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Support for OData (Azure Search)</link> for details).
trans-unit.target: The Azure Search Service API supports two syntaxes for entity lookup: simple and alternative OData syntax (see <link xlink:href="9274de9b-5faa-449b-9c5f-1ff54aa3afd9" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Support for OData (Azure Search)</link> for details).

trans-unit.source: The following list shows the simple syntax
trans-unit.target: The following list shows the simple syntax

trans-unit.source: For information about programming tasks and what order to perform them in, see <externalLink><linkText>Azure Search development workflow</linkText><linkUri>http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/articles/search-workflow/</linkUri></externalLink>.
trans-unit.target: For information about programming tasks and what order to perform them in, see <externalLink><linkText>Azure Search development workflow</linkText><linkUri>http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/articles/search-workflow/</linkUri></externalLink>.

trans-unit.source: To create the service and then experiment with the API using an HTTP diagnostic tool like Fiddler or Chrome Postman, see <externalLink><linkText>Create an Azure Search service</linkText><linkUri>http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/articles/search-create-service-portal/</linkUri></externalLink>, followed by <externalLink><linkText>How to use Fiddler with Azure Search</linkText><linkUri>http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/articles/search-fiddler</linkUri></externalLink> or <externalLink><linkText>How to use Chrome Postman with Azure Search</linkText><linkUri>http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/articles/search-chrome-postman/</linkUri></externalLink>.
trans-unit.target: To create the service and then experiment with the API using an HTTP diagnostic tool like Fiddler or Chrome Postman, see <externalLink><linkText>Create an Azure Search service</linkText><linkUri>http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/articles/search-create-service-portal/</linkUri></externalLink>, followed by <externalLink><linkText>How to use Fiddler with Azure Search</linkText><linkUri>http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/articles/search-fiddler</linkUri></externalLink> or <externalLink><linkText>How to use Chrome Postman with Azure Search</linkText><linkUri>http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/articles/search-chrome-postman/</linkUri></externalLink>.
